newsitem.title: INDIA: Cotton - Indian prices seen firming ahead of monsoon.
newsitem.headline: Cotton - Indian prices seen firming ahead of monsoon.

text.p: Cotton prices are expected to remain firm in May, ahead of monsoon rains, with the bulk of the 1996/97 (October/September) crop having been marketed already, traders said on Thursday.
"In the short-term, cotton prices are likely to remain firm due to limited supplies available and higher export demand for cotton yarn," said Manubhai Amarsey, a leading cotton trader.
Traders said the supplies were limited as lthe bulk of the 1996/97 crop, estimated at 16 million bales (one bale is 170 kg) had already arrived in the market.
"The long-term trend, however, will depend on the monsoon," Amarsey said. India's cotton crop depends mainly on the four-month June-September monsoon.
"If monsoon commences on time and spreads out evenly then cotton prices will fall," Amarsey said. If the monsoon is delayed then prices will spurt."
In the week to Wednesday, cotton prices bounced back from reduced levels on limited arrivals and unseasonal rains, traders said. The market was closed on Thursday for a local holiday.
"Most of the new crop in the northern and western India has already been marketed and only supplies from southern India are expected,"said Amarsey.
"Unseasonal rains in cotton-producing centres had also led to poor arrivals and affected the quality of cotton," he said.
Fresh demand from cotton yarn and textile mills had been poor but rising prices and limited supplies triggered some speculative buying, traders said.
In spot, Bengal-deshi rose 15/25 rupees at 885/935 rupees per maund (37.32 kg) and Punjab saw-ginned gained 50/80 rupees to 1,600/1,700 rupees per maund.
F-414 rose 55/70 rupees to 1,900/1,925 rupees per maund. Gujarat Kalyan (medium-staple) gained 400/500 rupees to 13,700/14,000 rupees per candy (355.56 kg).
Long-staple Gujarat Sankar-4 rose 1,500/3,000 rupees to 17,000/20,000 rupees per candy.
